I guess my point is there will always be political disagreements regardless of how the FCC is structured. battle lines will differ though.
if Title II had been agreed upon by both parties, it wouldn't have been a 10 year fight or an incredibly fraught issue.
article also misses that *most* FCC decisions are still 5-0. big-name decisions are by definition political b/c of the infighting.
when one party values primarily economic analysis, and another values how to use gov't to benefit consumers prescriptively, majority matters
sure we can *desire* that multiple parties agree/get along, but 3-2 majority is designed to give president's party the upper hand
most obvious question from @drj_policy's article: if FCC was meant to be apolitical, why create a 3-2 agency? https://t.co/9wPpVwCc2d
1. you alienate press 2. press stops covering you to stop giving you attention 3. you get to do whatever you want without accountability.
